writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?
story:
Neal Caffrey had always been a man of split-second decisions, a life lived on the edge of both legality and morality. As he sat in his loft, the city’s lights twinkling through the large windows, he couldn’t shake the feeling of unease that had settled in his gut. Mozzie had just left, his words still echoing in the silence.

“It’s the perfect job, Neal. One last heist, and we’re set for life. Think about it.”

Neal swirled the wine in his glass, staring into the dark liquid as if it held the answers he sought. The plan was flawless, the target tantalizing. Yet, for the first time, he hesitated. Was it because the job felt wrong, or because he felt wrong?

He glanced at the anklet on his leg, a constant reminder of his status as an FBI consultant. Peter Burke had taken a chance on him, seen something worth redeeming. Neal had always danced on the line, but now he wondered if he was starting to see the other side more clearly.

The door to his loft opened, and Neal turned to see Peter standing there, his expression a mix of concern and curiosity. “Mozzie left in a hurry,” Peter said, closing the door behind him. “Everything alright?”

Neal sighed, setting the wine glass down. “I’m not sure, Peter. Mozzie proposed a job. A big one.”

Peter raised an eyebrow, taking a seat across from Neal. “And you’re considering it?”

“That’s the thing,” Neal said, running a hand through his hair. “I don’t know if I am. For the first time, it doesn’t feel right.”

Peter leaned forward, his eyes searching Neal’s. “You’ve come a long way, Neal. Maybe this is a sign that you’ve changed more than you realize.”

Neal chuckled, but there was no humor in it. “Or maybe I’m just fooling myself. Maybe I’m still the same guy, just playing a different game.”

Peter shook his head. “You’re not the same guy. The Neal Caffrey I met would have jumped at this opportunity without a second thought. The fact that you’re hesitating means something.”

Neal looked at Peter, the man who had become not just his handler, but a friend. He thought about Elizabeth, their home, the life they had built. He thought about Sara, and the possibility of a future he had never dared to dream of before.

“You really believe that?” Neal asked, his voice quiet.

“I do,” Peter said firmly. “You’ve proven yourself time and again. To me, to the team, to yourself. This decision, whatever you choose, doesn’t define who you are. Your actions do. And you’ve shown that you’re capable of more than you ever thought.”

Neal took a deep breath, feeling the weight of Peter’s words. He had spent so long defining himself by his past, by his mistakes. But maybe it was time to start defining himself by his choices, by the person he wanted to be.

“I think I’m going to pass on Mozzie’s job,” Neal said finally, the decision settling in his chest like a weight lifted. “It’s not who I want to be anymore.”

Peter’s smile was warm, proud. “That’s the Neal I’ve come to know. You’re making the right choice.”

Neal nodded, a sense of peace washing over him. For the first time in a long time, he felt like he was on the right path. It wouldn’t be easy, and there would always be temptations, but he was ready to face them.

“Thanks, Peter,” Neal said, standing up and extending his hand. Peter took it, giving it a firm shake.

“Anytime, Neal. You know that.”

As Peter left, Neal stood by the window, looking out at the city he had once sought to conquer. Now, it was a city where he sought redemption, where he hoped to build a new life. The crossroads he faced was daunting, but he knew he wasn’t facing it alone.

He picked up his phone, dialing Mozzie’s number. The call was brief, but it conveyed everything it needed to. Mozzie was disappointed, but Neal knew his friend understood, even if he didn’t agree.

Neal set the phone down, feeling a sense of finality. He wasn’t just a master art forger anymore, or even just an FBI consultant. He was Neal Caffrey, a man who had made mistakes, but was determined to make amends.

And for the first time, he felt like he was on the right side of the line.

writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.
story:
The bar was dimly lit, the smell of cheap whiskey and regret lingering in the air. Crowley had no reason to be in this rundown dive, but the pull of nostalgia had brought him here. It was an odd place to find solace, but then again, he was an odd man.

He took a sip of his drink, savoring the burn as it slid down his throat. The years had not been kind to him, but they had also not been unkind. His empire was stable, his enemies mostly vanquished, and yet, something was missing. Or rather, someone.

Just as he was about to drown himself in another glass, the door creaked open, and in walked Dean Winchester. Crowley nearly choked on his drink. It had been years since he'd seen the hunter-turned-lawyer, and the sight of him still sent a jolt through his system. Dean looked older, more worn, but still undeniably handsome.

Dean’s eyes scanned the room, landing on Crowley with a mix of surprise and something that looked suspiciously like relief. He made his way over, and Crowley couldn’t help but smirk. “Well, if it isn’t the prodigal son.”

Dean chuckled, taking the seat next to him. “Crowley. It’s been a while.”

“Indeed it has. What brings you to this charming establishment?”

Dean shrugged, signaling the bartender for a drink. “Needed a break from the chaos. You?”

Crowley raised his glass. “Nostalgia, mostly. And perhaps a touch of masochism.”

They fell into a comfortable silence, the years of distance melting away as if they’d never been apart. It wasn’t long before the conversation turned to their past, the battles they’d fought side by side, the betrayals, the near-misses.

“I heard you went legit,” Dean said, a teasing glint in his eye. “Running a clean business these days?”

Crowley snorted. “As clean as it gets in my line of work. And you? Still playing hero?”

Dean’s smile faltered for a moment. “Tried that. Didn’t quite stick. Turns out, being a lawyer isn’t all that different from hunting. Just a different kind of monster.”

Crowley raised an eyebrow. “And which do you prefer?”

Dean’s gaze softened, and he looked at Crowley with an intensity that made his heart race. “Depends on the company.”

The night wore on, and the drinks kept coming. They reminisced, laughed, and somewhere between the second and third round, the confessions began. Crowley found himself opening up in a way he hadn’t in years, and Dean matched him word for word.

“I missed you, you know,” Dean admitted, his voice barely above a whisper.

Crowley’s breath hitched. “I missed you too.”

It was a moment of vulnerability that neither of them could ignore. They leaned in, and before Crowley knew it, Dean’s lips were on his. It was a kiss that tasted of whiskey and longing, and it left them both breathless.

When they finally pulled away, Dean rested his forehead against Crowley’s. “What are we doing?”

“Rewriting the plan,” Crowley replied, his voice steady despite the chaos in his mind.

The weeks that followed were a whirlwind. They found themselves tangled in each other’s lives in ways they hadn’t anticipated. Crowley’s business, though still operating in the shadows, became more efficient with Dean’s legal expertise. Dean, on the other hand, found himself navigating a world he thought he’d left behind, but this time with Crowley by his side.

And then there were the federal agents. It wasn’t long before their activities attracted attention, and they found themselves under scrutiny. But instead of running, they faced it head-on, using their combined skills to stay one step ahead.

It wasn’t easy, and there were nights when the weight of it all seemed too much. But in those moments, they found solace in each other. Late-night confessions became a ritual, stolen kisses a promise of more to come.

The turning point came during a family barbecue at the Winchester’s. Crowley had never been one for domesticity, but standing there, beer in hand, watching Dean laugh with his brother and his family, he realized this was what he’d been missing.

Sam approached him, a knowing smile on his face. “Didn’t think I’d see the day when you’d be part of a family gathering.”

Crowley shrugged, a rare smile tugging at his lips. “Life’s full of surprises.”

As the night wore on, Crowley found himself pulled into conversations, into the warmth of a family he never thought he’d have. And when Dean pulled him aside, wrapping an arm around his waist and whispering, “Thank you for being here,” Crowley knew he’d rewrite the plan a thousand times over for this.

Because some things, some people, were worth it.

writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.
story:
Neal Caffrey lounged in his chair, the picture of nonchalance, as he spun a silver pen between his fingers. The FBI conference room was a whirlpool of tension and debate, agents arguing over the next steps in their high-stakes art forgery case. Peter Burke, his handler and friend, watched the scene unfold with a furrowed brow, arms crossed over his chest.

"Look, we can't just barge into the gallery without a warrant," one of the junior agents insisted, his voice rising in frustration. "We need probable cause, or the evidence will be inadmissible in court."

"Probable cause? The guy's practically waving a red flag in our faces!" another agent shot back. "We don't need to wait for a judge's permission."

Neal's eyes flickered with a mix of amusement and disbelief. He'd seen this before – the classic battle between impatience and protocol. He leaned forward, setting the pen down with a soft click.

"Actually," Neal began, his voice cutting through the cacophony, "the junior agent has a point."

The room fell silent, all eyes turning to Neal. Peter's lips twitched in the slightest hint of a smirk. Oh, this was going to be good.

Neal stood, straightening his tie. "If we rush in without a warrant, anything we find could be thrown out. Our perp walks free, and we’re back to square one."

"You're siding with the bookworms now, Caffrey?" one of the senior agents scoffed, his disbelief palpable.

Neal's smile was razor-sharp. "I'm siding with the law. We need to do this by the book. Trust me, I've spent enough time circumventing it to know where the pitfalls are."

Peter couldn't hold back anymore. He let out a chuckle, drawing curious glances from the agents. "Neal Caffrey, defending proper legal procedures. I never thought I'd see the day."

Neal rolled his eyes, but there was a warmth in his gaze when it landed on Peter. "Times change, Peter. Even I know when to play it straight."

Peter stepped forward, his authoritative presence calming the room. "Neal's right. We need to do this by the book. Let's get the warrant and make sure every piece of evidence is airtight."

The junior agent, visibly relieved, nodded. "I'll get on it, sir."

As the agents dispersed to execute their revised plan, Peter sidled up to Neal, a teasing glint in his eyes. "Defending the law, huh? I think I might faint."

Neal shrugged, a mischievous smile playing on his lips. "Don't get used to it. I still have a reputation to uphold."

Peter laughed, clapping Neal on the shoulder. "Well, I won't let you live this down, that's for sure."

Neal sighed dramatically. "I figured as much."

They made their way out of the conference room, the tension of the earlier debate replaced by a newfound camaraderie. As they walked through the bustling FBI office, Neal couldn't help but feel a strange sense of satisfaction. It was an odd feeling, defending the very rules he'd once so gleefully broken. But then again, working with Peter had a way of changing perspectives.

Later that evening, as the team gathered in the bullpen to review the evidence they’d collected with their newly acquired warrant, Peter couldn't resist one last jab. "So, Neal, any more lectures on legal procedures you'd like to give?"

Neal smirked, leaning back in his chair. "Only if you promise to take notes, Peter."

The bullpen erupted in laughter, the day's stress melting away in the shared mirth. Peter shook his head, a fond smile on his face. "You know, Neal, you might just make a law-abiding citizen out of yourself yet."

Neal raised an eyebrow. "Don’t push your luck, Peter."

As the night wore on and the team delved deeper into their case, Neal found himself reflecting on how far he'd come. He'd started this journey as a con artist, a master of deception and manipulation. But now, working alongside Peter and the rest of the team, he'd discovered a new kind of thrill – the thrill of seeing justice done, of playing by the rules and still coming out on top.

And as much as he hated to admit it, maybe – just maybe – Peter's influence was rubbing off on him. Not that he'd ever give Peter the satisfaction of knowing that, of course.

Some secrets, after all, were worth keeping.

writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.
story:
Scotty’s hands trembled as he worked, the usual hum of the Enterprise eerily silent around him. The ship was dead in space, and every second felt like it was counting down to their doom. He'd been at it for hours, trying every trick he knew to get her back online, but the engines remained stubbornly inert.

"Damn it, lass," he muttered, patting the console as if it were a beloved pet. "What’s wrong with ye?"

The bridge was in chaos. Captain Kirk paced back and forth, his frustration and concern evident in every line of his body. Spock and McCoy were locked in a heated, albeit respectful, debate over potential causes and solutions.

"Kirk to Engineering," the captain's voice crackled over the intercom, strained but steady. "Scotty, any progress?"

Scotty wiped the sweat from his brow, his fingers pausing over the communicator. "No, sir," he replied, trying to keep his voice from shaking. "I’ve checked every system, run every diagnostic. There’s nae logical reason for the failure. It’s like she’s just... given up."

"Keep at it, Scotty," Kirk said, his tone softer now. "I know you’ll find a way."

"Aye, Captain," Scotty answered, though he wasn’t sure he believed it himself. 

He turned back to the console, brow furrowed in concentration. The Enterprise was more than just a ship to him; she was a living, breathing entity, and right now, she was hurting. But why? What had caused this sudden, catastrophic shutdown?

He thought back over the past few days. They’d been on a routine mission, nothing out of the ordinary. No anomalies, no encounters with hostile forces. Just a standard patrol through a sector of space that was supposed to be quiet.

Then it hit him. The nebula.

They'd passed through a nebula a few days ago, a beautiful swirl of colors that had fascinated the crew. Could something in the nebula have affected the ship? Some kind of unknown energy field?

His fingers flew over the controls, pulling up the data from their passage through the nebula. Sure enough, there it was – a spike in readings, something that had seemed insignificant at the time but now stood out like a beacon.

He ran a simulation, trying to isolate the energy signature. It took several agonizing minutes, but finally, he had it. An unknown form of radiation, subtle but pervasive, had infiltrated the ship’s systems.

"Scotty to Bridge," he said, his voice urgent. "I think I’ve found the problem. It’s the nebula. Some kind of radiation we didn’t detect at first. It’s affected the ship’s systems, causing the shutdown."

"Can you fix it?" Kirk’s voice was a lifeline, steady and strong.

"I can try," Scotty replied, already thinking through the steps. He’d need to purge the systems, recalibrate the shielding, and run a full diagnostic to ensure there was no lasting damage.

"Do it," Kirk ordered. "And Scotty – good work."

Scotty didn’t waste any time. He called in his team, explaining the situation and assigning tasks. They worked together like a well-oiled machine, every engineer knowing their role and executing it with precision.

Hours passed, the tension in the air thick enough to cut. Scotty barely noticed the passage of time, his focus entirely on the task at hand. He could feel the weight of the crew’s lives on his shoulders, but he pushed it aside, channeling all his energy into the work.

Finally, after what felt like an eternity, the systems began to come back online. The familiar hum of the engines was music to his ears, and he let out a breath he hadn’t realized he’d been holding.

"Scotty to Bridge," he said, unable to keep the relief out of his voice. "We’re back online, Captain. The radiation’s been purged, and the systems are stable."

"Well done, Scotty," Kirk replied, and Scotty could hear the smile in his voice. "You’ve saved us again."

"Just doing my job, sir," Scotty said, but he couldn’t help the swell of pride in his chest.

As the crew settled back into their routines, the crisis averted, Scotty took a moment to lean against the console, closing his eyes. The Enterprise was more than just a ship; she was a part of him, and he’d do whatever it took to keep her flying.

"Rest easy, lass," he whispered, patting the console affectionately. "We’re not done yet. Not by a long shot."

And with that, he turned back to his work, ready for whatever challenges lay ahead.

writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.
story:
Neal Caffrey's morning had started with a cup of coffee and a newly discovered Renoir forgery, which had led to Peter Burke's classic eyebrow raise—a look Neal had come to recognize as a mix of suspicion and begrudging admiration. But today, there was something more in Peter's eyes, something that told Neal this was not going to be an ordinary day.

"Neal, we have a situation," Peter said, his tone clipped.

"Isn't that every day?" Neal replied with a smirk, but it quickly faded when he saw the seriousness etched in Peter's face.

"Agent Keller from Internal Affairs is here. She's conducting an audit on our team and has raised concerns about a forgery linked to you."

Neal's heart skipped a beat. He knew his past was a minefield, but he had been walking the straight and narrow since he started working with Peter. "What forgery?"

"An original Renoir, supposedly authenticated by you. Keller thinks you were involved."

Neal's mind raced. He hadn't touched a paintbrush in months, let alone forged a masterpiece. "Peter, I swear, I didn't do it."

Peter's eyes softened for a moment. "I believe you, Neal. But Keller is relentless. We need to find out who set you up."

The door to Peter's office swung open, and Agent Keller strode in, her presence commanding the room. She was tall, with sharp features and an even sharper gaze. "Caffrey," she said, her voice like ice. "I've been looking forward to meeting you."

"Agent Keller," Neal replied, flashing his most charming smile. "I wish I could say the same."

Peter cleared his throat. "Keller, we were just discussing the Renoir case. Neal insists he had nothing to do with it."

Keller's eyes narrowed. "That's what they all say. But I have evidence that suggests otherwise."

"Evidence can be forged," Neal said, his tone measured. "And if there's one thing I know, it's forgery."

Keller smirked. "You're not helping your case, Caffrey. But go on, entertain me. How do you plan to prove your innocence?"

Neal glanced at Peter, who gave a slight nod. "Let me see the painting," Neal said. "I might be able to spot something that can lead us to the real forger."

Keller hesitated, then nodded. "Fine. But I'm watching you, Caffrey. One wrong move, and you're back in prison."

The painting was brought in, and Neal scrutinized it carefully. As he examined the brushstrokes, the texture, and the signature, he felt a sense of familiarity. Not with the painting itself, but with the style. He had seen this technique before.

"Gotcha," Neal muttered under his breath.

"What is it?" Peter asked.

"This isn't just any forgery," Neal explained. "It's the work of someone I know. An old rival—Vincent Adler. He always had a thing for Renoir."

Keller crossed her arms. "And why should we believe you?"

"Because Adler and I have a history," Neal said, his voice steady. "He'd love nothing more than to see me take the fall for his work. And he's good enough to pull it off."

Keller raised an eyebrow. "So what's your plan, Caffrey?"

Neal leaned back, a glint of determination in his eyes. "We set a trap. Adler won't be able to resist showing off his work. We just need to lure him out."

Peter frowned. "Neal, this sounds risky."

"I know," Neal admitted. "But it's the only way to clear my name and keep your team out of trouble."

Keller studied Neal for a moment, then nodded. "Alright, Caffrey. You have one chance. Don't mess it up."

Neal's plan involved staging an art exhibit featuring rare Renoirs, with the forgery as the centerpiece. Invitations were sent out discreetly, ensuring Adler would get wind of it. Neal knew Adler's ego wouldn't let him stay away.

The night of the exhibit arrived, and Neal stood by the forged Renoir, scanning the crowd. Peter and Keller were nearby, ready to move at a moment's notice. Neal's heart pounded as he spotted a familiar face entering the gallery.

Vincent Adler.

Adler approached the painting, a satisfied smirk on his face. "Beautiful, isn't it?" he said to Neal.

"It is," Neal replied, keeping his tone casual. "Almost perfect. But there's one tiny flaw."

Adler's eyes narrowed. "What flaw?"

Neal leaned in, his voice barely above a whisper. "The forger's ego. You couldn't resist, could you, Vincent?"

Before Adler could react, Peter and Keller moved in, placing him under arrest. Adler's smirk vanished, replaced by a look of shock.

As Adler was led away, Keller turned to Neal. "You did it, Caffrey."

Neal shrugged, a hint of a smile playing on his lips. "Just another day at the office."

Peter clapped Neal on the shoulder. "Good work, Neal. Now let's get back to catching the bad guys."

Neal grinned. "After this, I think I deserve a day off."

Peter chuckled. "Don't push your luck, Caffrey."

And with that, the unlikely team walked out of the gallery, ready for whatever came next.
